title: Tesla Earnings Live, 1st August, 2018
byline: Dan McCrum, Jamie Powell, Alexandra Scaggs
bodyHTML:
SupposeToBeWorking... evening all
9:33 pm
DM9:33pm

Hello, hello, good evening

hedgehog Numbers look ok ?
DM9:34pm

Welcome to this special edition of Tesla Markets Live Mega Earnings edition

DM9:34pm

Where we do the thing with the typing, but dedicate it all to Elon Musk

onrollover Cash position looks good. Not going bankrupt anytime this century.
9:35 pm
DM9:35pm

I should be joined by Jamie and Alex over here shortly, but technology...

DM9:35pm

Hang on, I'll give the hamster wheel a kick

Ken M Oh boy.
JP9:38pm

Evening everyone

9:38 pm
JP9:38pm

Hello!

Driss large increase in accounts payable
Driss 400mm, guess thats why cash looks better
JP9:38pm

So Musk is still a genius business visionary

DM9:39pm

Hello

9:39 pm
DM9:39pm

Welcome

JP9:40pm

Should we start with the top line numbers Dan?

Robert Smith FT’s Vancouver bureau here. What’s the HY bond doing? (5.3% 2025 note)
DM9:40pm

9:40 pm
DM9:40pm

$312, up 3.71 per cent

DM9:40pm

After hours

So, tell us, what do they look like?

9:40 pm
JP9:41pm

Must be impressed by the gross margin figure

DM9:41pm

(Hello Rob!)

Driss "we expect to increase production over the next few quarters beyond 6k per week" lol
DM9:42pm

(Hopefully Alex'll be able to tell us when she joins in)

Call me Papi whats after-hours atm? +4.7%?
9:42 pm
JP9:43pm

The market wizards at Barclays saw automative gross margin at 14.9 per cent, and the consensus was in the 17 per cent range.

JP9:43pm

Tesla beat significantly - 20.6 per cent

Randy Waterhouse And guide Q3 model 3 production at <5000/week
DM9:43pm

Omg smile

9:43 pm
JP9:44pm

Perhaps the Model 3 is profitable after all?

DM9:44pm

That seems like a lot of profit

Stemberger Increase in accounts payable is great for those future refunds from suppliers.
DM9:44pm

All of it from non-Model 3 though, right

doeswalk @onrollover $2.78 billion / $739.5 million a quarter = 3.75 quaters = just yes than a year no?
Puntino Though GM drops to 15.8% when you include the service losses.
9:44 pm
DM9:45pm

Model 3 gross margin turned slightly positive in Q2, expecting roughly 15% in Q3

JP9:46pm

True, but as Model 3's were around 45 per cent of deliveries, definitely helped.

DM9:46pm

And, as we looked at last week, Tesla's gross margin is a bit special

red lets see them stop buring cash and make a profit... a sustainable one quarter after quarter after quarter. you know, like toyota and the others do.
onrollover Yes glad to see accounts payable going in the right direction, nowhere near the levels of GM, Ford etc. a lot of suppliers are buggers to Tesla.
9:46 pm
DM9:47pm

So, what else?

JP9:49pm

Despite the gross margin beat, operating losses were heavier than expected.

onrollover Ha just less than a year if they manage to make no money on all they have invested in.
DM9:49pm

Go on

9:50 pm
DM9:50pm

Actually, here's a thought from a skeptical reader

JP9:50pm

Analysts pegged net income at -$490m

DM9:50pm

Rising revenues with dramatically higher gross margin should have led to much lower operating loss (or, indeed, a profit). Here, though, negative EBIT improved only slightly (-565MM Q2 compared to -$629MM Q1)

Results again show how meaningless Tesla's gross margin is.

onrollover Who cares about profit. Capital efficient growth is what is needed.
Stemberger No update on reservation/cancellation numbers, anyone find that odd?
9:50 pm
JP9:51pm

Figure came in at -$620m

JP9:52pm

Which sort of throws Nomura's theory out the window that "operating leverage in the Tesla model is much greater than many investors realise".

Randy Waterhouse "In recent weeks, orders from non reservation holders have already become a significant portion of our total new Model 3 orders, suggesting that we have barely tapped the full potential of Model 3 demand."Does that mean that people aren't converting reservations?
red who cares about profit? really
DM9:52pm

Yeah, not an enormous amount of evidence for that yet

9:52 pm
JP9:52pm

Great point, Randy.

DM9:53pm

Presumably reservations would put you first in the queue

DM9:53pm

Should be questions about that on the call, one might think

9:53 pm
JP9:53pm

We've heard a lot about the "off-the-wall" demand (or equivalent wording) for the Model 3. Why so early on the direct orders with a giant reservation backlog?

Driss or most of the reservations are for the 35k imaginary model
JP9:54pm

You'd hope so, Dan.

DM9:54pm

Goldman had an interesting bit about buzz in their preview

red this
onrollover Reservation number isn’t a useful metric anymore as they are now taking orders in the US and Canada without reservation.
9:54 pm
DM9:54pm

we also looked to gauge sentiment on the Model 3 with an analysis based on daily Twitter and Reddit posts (Exhibit 2). Posts are categorized into basic positives, basic negatives, and neutral buckets. We then subtract the number of negative posts
from the positive posts and divide by total posts to develop the sentiment skew within social media. From the data, we see a few trends:

DM9:54pm

DM9:55pm

Now, that might be skewed by all the nasty short sellers on twitter

red where is the affordable 35k model
9:55 pm
DM9:55pm

But GS go on:

Puntino Why has net debt gone from $ 6.35bln to $ 8.82bln if cash outflow was only $ 1.9bln.
DM9:55pm

Weekly posts about the Model 3 are declining: with 2016 averaging 4,400/week, 2017 averaging 3,900/week, and YTD 2018 averaging 3,000/week

DM9:55pm

Positive skew has faded: with 2016 carrying a +18% positive skew, 2017 a 12% positive skew, and YTD 2018 tracking at a 4.5% positive skew;

red whats the average sale price of their model 3? how does it comapre to the 35k initial offer.
Driss red, same place as the semi, model y and pickup
9:55 pm
DM9:56pm

With the recent increased availability of the Model 3 and increased production, we note a lack of peak (which would indicate significant buzz around the product) in social media posts;

DM9:56pm

Lastly, we find that sentiment has recently declined from a slightly positive skew (i.e., from +5% in 1H18) to a slightly negative skew the past few weeks 0 corresponding with the time period where the vehicle began to hit stores and orders were opened to all.

red wonder what we will hear about this time, to raise the next 2 yards.
JP9:57pm

Puntino: maybe Tesla is extending its other credit lines? I do recall it has an ABL.

9:57 pm
DM9:58pm

Current portion of long term debt and leases up a lot

red tesla shareholders have a fair amount to worry about in house, but lets be honest the european japanese offerings are beginning to look rather good. and of course they do have the ability to produce and sell millions of cars a year. and make a profit on them, would you believe.
JP9:59pm

A lack of buzz around the Model 3? It's hard to remember but the car was announced over 2 years ago -- time and hype don't mix well.

DM9:59pm

Working Capital also worth a look

9:59 pm
JP9:59pm

A quick point on gross margins while Dan opens up the cash flow statement

red i suggest other makers offerings are taking interest from tesla. from nothing to talk about to something to talk about. competition.
JP10:01pm

via Twitter, paraphrased: "SG&A and R&D reported a $80m increase, versus $30m sequentially for the previous four quarters. Flip that back to gross margins where it may belong and Gms decline 100 bps"

onrollover Hang on US and Canada reservations are only going to be max 170k they are taking orders up to the end of the year now, which basically means more than half of the reservation holders in US have already ordered. They haven’t sold a single car under 49k, it’s a bit much to suggest the majority will be at 35k.
AS10:02pm

Hi folks -- looking forward to getting Jamie's take on gross margins

10:02 pm
JP10:02pm

Remember, CNBC reported yesterday that Tesla was pulling in extra workers from its service centers, so the point may stand.

Stemberger onrollover, they are taking orders for higher priced cars if I'm not mistaken. Why would the demand for higher priced model 3 be equal to the reserved $35k version?
DM10:02pm

Hello Alex, welcome!

JP10:02pm

Hello Alex! Please to have you here.

10:02 pm
AS10:02pm

heckuva quarter eh?

JP10:02pm

always Alex, always.

DM10:03pm

Well, look at Working Capital

10:02 pm
JP10:03pm

How's it looking Dan?

DM10:03pm

As it is put to me

red for them a 35k model is clearly not commercially viable, otherwise they would have done it.
DM10:03pm

Working Capital, which is Current Assets minus Current Liabilities on the balance sheet. Tesla’s Working Capital was negative $2.27 billion at the end of Q1. This number is more important than cash on hand. Cash on hand can be distorted by accepting Customer Deposits (which are liabilities on the balance sheet), by borrowing money under the lines of credit, and by stretching out vendors (thereby increasing Accounts Payable). Working Capital gives you important information about whether the health of the company is improving or deteriorating.

onrollover Why make the low margin cars first, makes no sense.
10:03 pm
DM10:03pm

So instead of cash balances, look at working Capital

DM10:04pm

For Tesla, working capital is now NEGATIVE $2.44 billion. The most negative ever, and not exactly a healthy sign.

onrollover Better to get the production system up and running, up sell as much as you can then bring out the low cost.
red well they took reservations for them didnt they? and you said profit doesnt matter right?
KNM Sorry, new here. Is there audio on the site that will link in the call?
JP10:04pm

Also worth pointing out that if you look at cash, do remember that customer deposits sit at around 47 per cent of the $2.2bn on the balance sheet.

Provender In the M3 buzz they've announced today fee supercharging on the M3 performance with referral. Trying hard to encourage upgrades
onrollover Overall profitability doesn’t matter. Gross margin does because that’s more capital to invest.
Stemberger They took reservations on a $35k car. SO WHERE IS IT?
10:04 pm
DM10:05pm

And on the gross margin point above, R&D increased from $367m in Q1 to $386m in Q2. I guess when engineers go work on the production line, their salaries remain in R&D.

red right so folks will be waiting for their delivery for how many years? 3, 4 or 5? that makes sense. maybe they will just go out and buy the 35k toyota or vw.
Provender When they can buy a 200+ mile EV from major manufacturers I'm sure they will
DM10:06pm

Also look at Capex

onrollover Why by the 35k car when you could spend a bit more and get more range, who in their right mind would buy a Tesla without the 5k EAP option.
Robert Smith Scaggs, gimme dat HY bond price. London clearly don’t have a BBG to hand.
bulldog2015 Does anyone have a sense why their deferred revenues dropped off so much? I wonder if they are becoming more aggressive in booking revenue to juice the top line. That could also explain why their gross margins improved.
DM10:06pm

This is a successful company with big plans right?

David Gerard KNM: the site is edge.media-server.com/m6/p/wasrmjwi - live call doesn't start until 10:30pm BST
10:06 pm
DM10:06pm

China, Gigafactory, a big semi truck

DM10:07pm

And yet the Capex line is, going down?

onrollover On resale’s on model S EAP does not depreciate, so it doesn’t cost you anything.
DM10:07pm

Tesla initially guided for $3.4B of 2018 Cap Ex. Cut that to $3.0B last quarter. Now, cut again to less than $2.5B. So, where does the money come from to do all those great new things?

10:07 pm

One place might be the local Chinese bond market

heh

KNM Thanks. The violins are singing.

according to the presser: "Construction is expected to start within the next few quarters, though our initial investment will not start in any significant way until 2019, with much of it expected to be funded through local debt."

10:08 pm
JP10:08pm

This is, of course, the Gigafactory 3 in Shanghai.

red who needs money when you can tweet
DM10:09pm

You know how many people are going to be working on that construction site?

Provender @onrollover dunno whether that translates to same monthly payment on pcp tho, 35k buyers likely price-constrained
AS10:10pm

How many?

10:10 pm

About 500,000 I hear

onrollover Well you hit on another reason why some haven’t ordered. no PCP is currently available on Model 3. Gosh it’s almost as if they have massive demand and are production constrained.
red far fewer folks can afford a 60k car compared to 35k car. and besides, if you tell them 35k and they base their decision on this, either build it or give cash back.
Honest Abe Anybody else enjoy #Chartmas? https://twitter.com/TeslaCharts
AS10:11pm

haaaaaaa

JP10:11pm

I see what you did there.

10:11 pm
JP10:12pm

Honest Abe - yes we did. Stellar work as always.

DM10:12pm

we wish it could be chartmas every day

JP10:12pm

Back to the working capital. Inventories are also 30 per cent higher this quarter, growing faster than revenues (17 per cent sequentially).

onrollover It becomes more complicated when you get to the decision to order a 35k Tesla has significantly cheaper total cost of ownership than a 35k ICE a lot that ordered probably didn’t realise how well the sums work out for them.
red nice@DM
10:12 pm

about those HY bonds

DM10:13pm

oooh, higher or lower?

they're up a bit! at last check they're trading at 89.25 on the dollar, up from 88.75 yesterday

RocketRocketRocket

Maybe third quarter profits are possible after all

Quickly on inventories: of $3.3bn, finished goods are $1.7bn. If we're reading between the lines correctly.

a 51 per cent increase sequentially.

That's a lot of cars.

onrollover That was the story for the model s. You may not remember but they also advertised a lower price than was ever initially available, but people still bought in large numbers and stretched their budgets.
Robert Smith Coupon is 5.3. And the funny thing about that is bond market convention is quarters and eighths, and it was indicated it would be 5.25. But then it got bumped up to 5.3, supposedly in homage to the Model 3. So they’re paying extra interest in the name of symbolism...
AS10:16pm

Rob, to da moon! or perhaps mars

Driss they never made any profit on the s
red folks buying 100k cars have the ability to stretch their budget further than those on a 35k budget.
red profits dont matter apparently
doeswalk @Robert ha really

Leading on Autopilot is a bold choice, given the churn in the department recently.

red well all that time in the body shop takes its toll right
Honest Abe Wait, Stuart gets to leave work? So unfair.
onrollover The problem with shorts is that you keep forgetting, Tesla is innovating fast. Always new stuff coming. Tesla makes its capital expenditure work harder than any other company.

But of course, the autopilot upgrade is pretty accretive to gross margins. At last viewing it was $5k more on the Model 3.

David Gerard from somethingawful: " they gave him the natural calming treats dogs get when they're scared of thunderstorms "

@Puntino, very interesting.
